title: Observation of Thermal Current-Driven Spin Texture Dynamics in (Fe0.63Ni0.3Pd0.07)3P via Lorentz Transmission Electron Microscopy
content: Topological spin textures called magnetic skyrmions (Sky) [1, 2] can be driven into motion via an electric [3] or thermal [4] current, and can even transform into their topological antiparticles, antiskyrmions (Asky) [5], via application of heat and an external magnetic field [6]. Due to their low energy controllability and topological protection, these spin textures are heralded as key components of future spintronics technology. To realize such a future, it is critical to identify and assess external stimuli by which these spin textures may be controlled. Thermal current is of particular interest because of the possibility of recycling waste heat inherent to all energy-driven technology, which would ultimately increase the efficiency of the energy cycle.
